My fight for better design started by realizing that it was up to me, a developer trainee at Nokia, to decide how a web application should work. I had no idea what most of the data handled by that website meant. Oh, KPI stands for key performance indicator? Still boggled. Who found these indicators valuable and why? Since then, I've made sure to always answer that question first.{" "}

Surveys

To be fair, at Nokia we knew exactly who was using the system as well as the indented purpose. I just didn't know how. Since then, I've started several projects by conducting online surveys. They haven't failed me in directing a design towards the right way during case winning hackathon projects and best graded university courses. Once prospective, active or past users have been reached, getting to know them personally, statistically and as the users of your product is everything.

Aloha

Fast forward a couple of years, I started working as a UX designer at a startup called Elk, where I had done my thesis while studying human-computer interaction and design at KTH in Stockholm. The new goals set during a pandemic spring required prompt action to find the right direction. As we set out to develop the{" "} Aloha service to enable musicians to work remotely, instead of the familiar B2B approach, one had to not only reach enthusiastic users, but also map out their needs, desires and attitudes. As my first task, I drafted an extensive user study based on experience gained during business development labs at the EIT Digital master school. The study eventually reached 445 volunteer beta testers and helped our developer team to prioritize features, me to realize how they should be implemented and the CFO, who found the results "extremely valuable", with the pricing of the product.

Oasis

During The Sthlm Tech Fest 2019, our team developed a platform, Oasis, which enabled collectively sharing and building green areas in the urban environment. The owners (be it a city, an organization or an individual) of green areas could find gardeners to maintain or to fully design it, responding to the needs of those living in a small city flat with a longing for gardening and significantly reducing the costs of keeping public spaces attractive. Reaching out to prospective users, such as young adults and the city of Stockholm, proved that the value provided by the platform well represented those of the company: mental health, community and both environmental and financial sustainability. As the secret usability sauce, Oasis attracted more inexperienced city gardeners with automated help e.g. notifications when plants needed watering, enabled by smart humidity sensors provided by the case owner.

{/* */}
Weather to wear

Another success was the development of "Weather to Wear", a web application for digitizing one's wardrobe. The environmental impact of the garment industry (20% of all water pollution) could be battled with a C2C business model integrated with an existing clothes-swapping platform, Vinted, with more than 1.5 million active daily users in France. Thanks to AI, Weather to Wear matched personalized suggestions on what to wear or pack for a trip with the weather conditions and based on statistics, could identify which clothing items the user could get rid of or get from other users with the touch of a button. Thanks to a market research and an additional online survey, we could shape our business-worthy design and to identify our first users. We analysed 38 responses to the online survey and ran a statistical analysis in R studio regarding significant factors. We received a positive response after contacting the CEO, the head of engineering and the head of product at Vinted and were encouraged to keep on working on the platform.

Critical indicent technique

This is something I took away from my studies at Université Paris-Saclay (ranked 14th globally in the {""} Academic Ranking of World Universities 2020 ). Let's say you have an idea what to make and to whom, but you need to zoom into how to design it – kind of like the situation we had at Nokia. You need to ask the user to describe, in as much detail as possible, issues they faced and how they resolved them when using a specific interface. A protip is to choose a competitive solution or a previous version to the one you're working on, which will pinpoint at least some of the focus points of the following design. I've used it when designing AccessMap, a navigation app optimizing the most accessible routes, Part Planner, a collaborative party planner application and Squatle, a service for booking sports classes to name a few.

Observation (and vocalizing it)

Sometimes you need to hit the field (or create one) to acquire knowledge beyond words – I noticed this when designing digital interfaces for live musicians. As my thesis project, I designed a collaborative interface for adjusting digital audio effects of four instruments simultaneously in real-time. The participatory design process started by organizing workshops, where the musicians were instructed to perform different improvisation tasks to identify the main opportunities and challenges of digital audio effects in improvised live music. By socially engineering a real situation, more targeted and valuable observations about the use case could be vocalized and documented during the group discussions that followed. Regardless, I noticed that not everything valuable was mentioned during the discussions. Recording things said out loud while performing a task is crucial to me and in fact, I encourage users to speak up during the interaction with a system or a prototype as much as possible.{" "}

Personas and scenarios

Moving on to the analysis part of all the valuable knowledge acquired with the above techniques: constructing user personas and scenarios. I've noticed that this part might not be taken seriously, even though it beautifully merges a lot of intrinsic knowledge in a motivating and easy-to-grasp way for the whole team.
